item.title: Widening Mideast Crisis: E.U. Meeting Highlights Disconnect With Israel Over War Plans
item.description: At the European Union’s headquarters in Brussels, officials were confused by Israel’s presentation and pressed for recognition of the importance of moving toward a Palestinian state.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinian boys inspect the remains of a car in Rafah, Gaza, on Sunday.

item.title: In Ayodhya, Modi Opens Ram Temple in Triumph for Hindu Nationalists
item.description: The temple inaugurated by the prime minister is on the disputed site of a centuries-old mosque destroyed in a Hindu mob attack that set a precedent of impunity in cases of violence against Muslims.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal, Hari Kumar and Atul Loke
item.media:description: In front of the Ram temple in Ayodhya, in northern India.

item.title: Russian Celebrities Caught ‘Almost Naked’ Are Now Dressing to Appease
item.description: President Vladimir Putin derided those “jumping around without pants,” at a party, while some guests have tried to make amends through donations and adopting a cat.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne
item.media:description: A hedonistic party at a Moscow nightclub last month drew the ire of President Vladimir V. Putin and other Russians as the country’s troops fought in Ukraine.

item.title: Landslide in Southern China Buries Dozens and Sends Hundreds Fleeing
item.description: At least eight people died, and 39 others were under the rubble, the state media reported.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang

item.title: Sunak’s Rwanda Plan Fails First Test in House of Lords
item.description: In the latest setback to Prime Minister Rishi Sunak’s Rwanda policy, the upper house of the British Parliament voted to delay a crucial treaty with the African country.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.category: Supreme Court of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak during a visit to Britain’s National Film and Television School on Monday in Beaconsfield, England.

item.title: Elon Musk, on Rehabilitation Tour, Calls Himself ‘Aspirationally Jewish’
item.description: His remarks, part of an effort to atone for comments many called antisemitic, came after a visit to the Auschwitz death camp site.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Yoav Dudkevitch/European Jewish Association, via Reuters
item.media:description: Elon Musk during a visit on Monday to the Nazi death camp at Auschwitz.

item.title: What Is ‘Settler Colonialism’?
item.description: A look at the academic roots of the idea, which has stirred fierce debate when applied to Israel.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Schuessler
item.media:description: Pro-Palestinian activists at a rally in Washington in November.

item.title: As Switzerland’s Glaciers Shrink, a Way of Life May Melt Away
item.description: Rising temperatures and retreating glaciers threaten Europe’s water tower, forcing local farmers to adapt and presaging larger troubles downstream.
item.dc:creator: George Steinmetz and Catherine Porter
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization

item.title: Depardieu Sexual Assault Suit Dropped Over Statute of Limitations
item.description: Hélène Darras, a French actress, had accused Gérard Depardieu of groping her in 2007 on a movie set. A separate investigation of the actor is proceeding, Paris prosecutors said.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Gérard Depardieu, 75, has denied any wrongdoing, and he has not been convicted in connection with any of the accusations against him.

item.title: Is North Korea Planning a War?
item.description: An intensification of nuclear threats from North Korea while the world is preoccupied with other wars has ignited an urgent debate over Mr. Kim’s motives.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Reuters
item.media:description: In an image released this month by North Korea’s official news agency, Kim Jong-un is shown visiting a munitions plant.

item.title: Presidential Favorite in Indonesia Stirs Fears of ‘Death of Democracy’
item.description: Although he dons different personas, the strongman bona fides of Prabowo Subianto date to when Indonesia was a dictatorship led by his former father-in-law.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: Prabowo Subianto greeting supporters in Jakarta, Indonesia, in October. A victory for him in the presidential election, critics warn, could erode the country’s hard-won democracy.

item.title: In France, a Conviction for Police Brutality, but Little Expectation of Change
item.description: A police officer who seriously injured a 22-year-old Black man with a baton during an arrest in 2017 was convicted, but given only a suspended sentence.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Theo Luhaka, who was legally declared a victim of police brutality, on Friday in Bobigny, France.

item.title: Why India’s New Ram Temple in Ayodhya Is So Important
item.description: Its site is sacred to Hindus, and it also represents the much more recent victory of Hinduism as a political identity.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli and Hari Kumar
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Security was high at the temple before the consecration on Monday.

item.title: Taiwan’s Doubts About America Are Growing. That Could Be Dangerous.
item.description: Will deepening skepticism about the United States as a trustworthy nation diminish Taiwan’s belief that it could fend off China?
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave, Amy Chang Chien and Lam Yik Fei
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: There are markers all over Taiwan, like this one in Taipei, of its courtship of the United States.

item.title: Israel-E.U. Meeting on Gaza’s Future Yields Division and Confusion
item.description: Europeans, insisting on Palestinian statehood, are frustrated by Israel’s opposition and lack of a postwar plan for the devastated Gaza Strip.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Hiba Yazbek, Adam Rasgon, Monika Pronczuk and Michael Levenson
item.category: International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies
item.media:description: Foreign Minister Yisrael Katz of Israel holding up photos of hostages kidnapped during the Oct. 7 Hamas-led attack in Israel as he arrived for a meeting of E.U. foreign ministers in Brussels on Monday.

item.title: Bali Bombers May Return to Malaysia After Sentencing
item.description: The two prisoners have admitted to conspiring with an affiliate of Al Qaeda that carried out a deadly bombing in Indonesia two decades ago.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.media:description: Mohammed Farik Bin Amin, left, and Mohammed Nazir Bin Lep spent years in secret C.I.A. prisons after their capture in 2003.

item.title: Storm Isha Diverts Dozens of Flights From England and Ireland
item.description: Ferocious winds forced pilots to abort landings and divert passengers hundreds of miles from their original destinations.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch and Remy Tumin
item.media:description: Storm Isha caused airlines to cancel or divert dozens of flights in Britain and Ireland on Sunday and Monday.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: North Korean Missiles in Ukraine
item.description: Plus, a “revolutionary” way to feed the world.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: The aftermath of a Russian strike in Kyiv, Ukraine, in early January.

item.title: 1924: Protests Will Continue on Rum-Ship Seizures
item.description: The British authorities accused their American counterparts of seizing rum-runners outside an agreed-upon three-mile zone.
item.dc:creator: The International Herald Tribune

item.title: Blinken, in Cape Verde, Signals U.S. Attention to Africa
item.description: The secretary of state is beginning a tour of four African countries, hoping to promote positive news on the continent.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken toured the port of Praia in Cape Verde, which was renovated with nearly $55 million in U.S. aid more than a decade ago.

item.title: North Korean Missiles in Ukraine Prompt New Concerns
item.description: As the war approaches its second anniversary, the Russians are beginning to deploy North Korean arms, worsening Ukraine’s troubles while it still awaits new air defenses from the United States.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: The aftermath of a Russian strike in Kyiv, Ukraine, in early January.

item.title: Fighting Intensifies in Southern Gaza and Its Main City, Khan Younis
item.description: “The whole district of Khan Younis is essentially besieged,” a spokeswoman for the Palestinian Red Crescent Society said.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek and Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: Smoke over Khan Younis, seen from Rafah, in southern Gaza, on Monday.

item.title: Protesters Storm Israel’s Parliament as Anger Over Gaza Hostages Grows
item.description: Advocates and relatives of hostages urged lawmakers to do more to free their loved ones. “Shame on you!” one yelled.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon

item.title: In a sign of the war’s shift, daily deaths in Gaza are falling, data shows.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt

item.title: Sarah Ferguson, Duchess of York, Is Diagnosed With Skin Cancer
item.description: The ex-wife of Prince Andrew said it was a “shock” that doctors had discovered melanoma, a deadly form of skin cancer, just months after a breast cancer diagnosis last summer.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: JP Yim/Getty Images for Daughters for Earth
item.media:description: Sarah Ferguson, the Duchess of York, in New York in September.

item.title: An Italian Town Full of the Elderly Wants to Feel Young Again
item.description: San Giovanni Lipioni, a tiny town in central Italy, has one of the oldest average populations in the country but hopes a marketing push will attract younger people.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pietro Grosso, 18 months old, was the only child born in 2022 in San Giovanni Lipioni, Italy.

item.title: US Declares Two Missing Navy SEALs Dead in Somalia
item.description: The U.S. military has ended a 10 day search for the commandos who went overboard during the mission off the Somalia coast.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Iranian missiles in a park in Tehran, Iran, on Saturday. Two Navy SEALs died during a raid on a ship holding parts of missiles Iran was supplying to Houthi fighters in Yemen.

item.title: Israel’s foreign minister speaks in Brussels amid discord at home over the war.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: Photographs of people who were killed or taken hostage in the Oct. 7 Hamas-led attacks on a wall at a music festival in Re’im, Israel.

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: The latest from the war in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Family members of hostages and their supporters protested in Tel Aviv on Saturday.

item.title: As U.S. and Militias Engage, White House Worries About a Tipping Point
item.description: The number of attacks on American troops in the Middle East increases the risk of deaths, a red line that could lead to a wider war.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Yuri Gripas for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden boarding Marine One on Sunday. The latest attack on American troops over the weekend resulted in no deaths, but Mr. Biden and his advisers worry it is only a matter of time.

item.title: Monday Briefing: U.S. Pushes for New Hostage Talks
item.description: Plus the meaning of North Korea’s threats.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Families of hostages and supporters hold banners during a protest to call for the immediate release of hostages in Jerusalem on Sunday.

item.title: U.S. and European Officials Push for Gaza Aid to Pass Through Israeli Port
item.description: The ultimate goal, officials said, is to establish a workable alternative to delivering aid via Egypt in a way that satisfies Israel’s demand for security checks.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee, Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: Food being distributed to people in Rafah, southern Gaza, on Saturday.

item.title: Storm Isha Sweeps Britain With Powerful Winds, Disrupting Travel
item.description: Powerful winds swept the region overnight into Monday, causing travel disruptions and power outages. A second powerful storm is expected to bring similarly windy conditions.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:description: Waves hitting the shore in Porthleven, England, on Sunday.

item.title: U.N. Chief Says Gaza Death Toll Is ‘Unacceptable’ as It Passes 25,000
item.description: Palestinian authorities said on Sunday that more than 25,000 people had been killed in the Gaza Strip in the Israel’s military response to the Oct. 7 attacks.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: António Guterres, the secretary general of the United Nations, at a summit in Uganda on Sunday.

item.title: Deep Under Gaza, Israel Shows Evidence Hostages Were Held in Tunnels
item.description: The Israeli military took reporters on a tour of an underground compound in the Gazan city of Khan Younis, where it says about 20 hostages were held by Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: A soldier standing in an underground compound where the Israeli military said hostages had been held by Hamas, as photographed during an escorted tour.

item.title: Deadly Blast Hits Market in Russia-Held Donetsk, Ukraine, Officials Say
item.description: The pro-Moscow authorities in the eastern city of Donetsk said 25 people were killed and 20 others were wounded. It was not possible to independently confirm which side launched the strike.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: A market in Donetsk, Ukraine, that the Russia-installed local authorities said was shelled on Sunday.

item.title: Netanyahu Restates Opposition to Two-State Solution, Despite Pressure From Biden
item.description: The Israeli prime minister said that he had long opposed a Palestinian state because it would constitute “an existential danger to Israel.”
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: President Biden met Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and his war cabinet in October.

item.title: Israeli Strike in Syria Kills Iranian Officials and U.S. Troops Injured in Iraq
item.description: A senior Iranian intelligence official was killed in an Israeli strike in Damascus as U.S. troops came under attack in Iraq.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim, Hwaida Saad and Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Rescue workers and security forces gathering in front of a building in Damascus, Syria, that was destroyed in an Israeli attack on Saturday.

item.title: Palestinian American Teenager Killed in the West Bank Is Mourned
item.description: Tawfic Abdel Jabbar, 17, who was fatally shot on Friday, was raised in New Orleans and had planned to attend business school there.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin and Rami Nazzal
item.media:description: Mourners attending the funeral of Tawfic Abdel Jabbar, a 17-year-old Palestinian American who was killed in the occupied West Bank on Friday.

item.title: Lev Rubinstein, Russian Poet and a Critic of Putin, Is Dead at 76
item.description: He helped found an avant-garde movement fusing art and prose and was outspoken against the invasion of Ukraine. He died after he was hit by a car in Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Lev Rubinstein in 2004. “Today’s Russia has no place for free citizens and independent poets,” one tribute to him on social media said. “It barrels through them, not stopping at the red light to see them cross the road.”

item.title: A Plant That Flowers Underground Is New to Science, but Not to Borneo
item.description: The Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew, hailed pinanga subterranea, a palm native to the island, as a discovery, but it has long been known to local Indigenous people.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Hasya Nindita
item.media:credit: Agusti Randi, via Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew
item.media:description: The fruit of the Pinanga subterranea, which flowers underground, revealed by digging.

item.title: ‘No End in Sight’: Evacuated Israeli City Braces for Possible War With Hezbollah
item.description: As tensions escalated on Israel’s northern border with Lebanon after Oct. 7, Israel evacuated tens of thousands of residents from the region, including from Kiryat Shmona, a town with 24,000 people. Months later, evacuees remain in limbo, and the mayor insists they cannot return until Hezbollah militants are pushed back.
item.dc:creator: Guy Barak, David Blumenfeld, Caroline Kim and Brent McDonald
item.media:credit: David Blumenfeld for The New York Times

item.title: The Debate Over January
item.description: The seemingly trivial debate over the merits of winter offers an outlet for seasonal frustration.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: The Growing Private-Sector Involvement in Canadian Public Health Care Systems
item.description: Ontario announced plans this week to further expand services offered through privately owned clinics under its health plan.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: The Hospital for Sick Children in Toronto. Ontario is expanding private clinics.

item.title: Radio Station Captures Fears of Ukrainian City Under Siege
item.description: Kharkiv, in northern Ukraine, is under almost daily bombardment. Radio Boiling Over serves as a megaphone for residents’ fears and frustrations.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Maria Varenikova and Tyler Hicks
item.media:description: Yevhen Streltsov, right, the founder of “Radio Boiling Over,” a call-in radio station where residents of Kharkiv vent their frustration.

item.title: In Strategic Bind, Israel Weighs Freeing Hostages Against Destroying Hamas
item.description: Some Israeli commanders said the government’s two main goals were mutually incompatible. To eradicate Hamas, the military would have to engage in a lengthy war that would most likely cost the hostages’ lives.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Israeli soldier patrolling in Gaza, as photographed during an escorted tour by the Israeli military for international journalists.

item.title: Rare Earth Metals May Be Lurking in Your Junk Drawer
item.description: And that’s a good thing. They’re critical for renewable energy, and a new study says recovering them from old cellphones and other waste could help meet the demand.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Peter DaSilva for The New York Times
item.media:description: Only about 1 percent of rare earth metals in old electronic products are currently reused or recycled, researchers estimate.

item.title: Seoul Police Chief Charged in South Korea Crowd Crush
item.description: Kim Kwang-ho, charged with negligence, is one of the most senior officials to face legal consequences for the October 2022 disaster that killed nearly 160 people in Seoul.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: A view, the day after the disaster, of the alleyway in the Itaewon neighborhood of Seoul where most of the deaths took place.

item.title: Germans Push Back as Far Right’s Influence Grows
item.description: News of a secret meeting among extremists to discuss mass deportations, including of citizens from immigrant backgrounds, has shaken the society.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Demonstrators protesting the far-right Alternative for Germany party, known as AfD, in Berlin this week.

item.title: Italian Culture Official Investigated in Stolen Art Case
item.description: Prosecutors believe a painting the deputy culture minister, Vittorio Sgarbi, put on display in 2021 was in fact stolen in 2013. He says it’s a different copy.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Roberto Serra/Iguana Press, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Vittorio Sgarbi, an Italian politician and art historian, in Bologna, Italy, in 2018.

item.title: Dormitory Fire Kills 13 in Central China
item.description: The private school is for kindergarten and elementary school pupils. Though many details of the disaster remained unclear, it drew widespread attention on China’s internet.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: Police officers outside a school dormitory after a fire on Saturday in central Henan Province in China.

item.title: Quebec Man Pleads Guilty to What He Accused the Government Of: Starting Wildfires
item.description: A man who pleaded guilty to setting 14 fires in 2023 also shared misinformation and conspiracy theories about wildfires and climate change.
item.dc:creator: Delger Erdenesanaa
item.media:credit: Renaud Philippe for The New York Times
item.media:description: A fire in northern Quebec last June. The majority of fires were started by lightning strikes.

item.title: U.S. Strikes More Houthi Targets in Yemen
item.description: The strikes, the sixth round in 10 days, targeted Houthi missiles that were poised to attack merchant and military vessels in the Red Sea, according to a White House official.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: John Kirby, the National Security Council spokesman, gave a briefing at the White House on Friday.

item.title: French Police Officer Convicted in Théo Luhaka Abuse Case
item.description: Théo Luhaka, who was 22 at the time of the incident, sustained serious injuries when the police subdued him while conducting identity checks in a suburb northeast of Paris.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Théo Luhaka, who was beaten by the police, leaving the courthouse in Bobigny, near Paris, on Friday after hearing of the conviction of three police officers involved in the attack.

item.title: Prince Harry Withdraws Libel Claim Against Mail on Sunday Publisher
item.description: The prince had been suing Associated Newspapers over a 2022 article suggesting he misled the public over his security arrangements, claiming it was defamatory.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prince Harry leaving the Royal Courts of Justice, Britain’s High Court, in London in June.

item.title: Biden Presses Netanyahu on Working Toward a Palestinian State
item.description: The two leaders spoke for the first time in weeks. Their call came a day after the Israeli leader rebuffed U.S. efforts to pressure him into a two-state solution.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden expressed optimism that he and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel could still reach consensus. “There are a number of types of two-state solutions,” he said.

item.title: Annie Nightingale, Pathbreaking British D.J., Is Dead at 83
item.description: She was initially told there was no room for her on BBC Radio 1 because a woman’s voice lacked the authority of a man’s. Once she was on the air, she stayed there for 53 years.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:description: Annie Nightingale in 1970, the year she became the first female disc jockey on BBC Radio 1.
